posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This is not a mediocre build. Without using too strong words - it is worse. The saves are good, you have monk class features, And that's about it.
If you build for a high magic environment, you want to give the build features that won't come from items, such as Epic Dodge, SCV,  Divine Might and so on. Things that make you survive all spells, traps and a prolonged battle of 20s.
If you add too many item bonus features, any build becomes almost impossible to kill. Then the game loses all challenge and becomes pointless.

I am curious as to how you have tested this build and if your playing experience is any different from what I have outlined above.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
It has divine might, as an item property. That is why I chose paladin, because Cast Spell: Divine Might still spends Turn Undead. And yes, I was imagining this build engaging in a battle of 20s and that is why attacks per round, rather than AB is prioritized.

A build with epic dodge will not win against this build who has 10 APR. Sure he will miss the first attack each round, but he will still have more attacks, with more divine might damage. There is also a chance to kill the enemy with On Hit: Slay if they miss their saving throw.

So one gets more chances to roll a 20 and the other gets more chances to roll a 1 on a saving throw.

Cast Spell: Divine Might ignores SR. 
On hit: Slay ignores death magic immunity.

Admittedly, the point of this post is not only to show the build, but to show items that fits it like a glove. It actually required more planning and thought than the build itself, especially if considering the item level restriction and only up to eight bonuses per item.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
It’s the latter, thanks for pointing that out. Basically, it attempts to the answer the question of how strong can a player character get with level 40 gear. I’d like to be educated as well if there’s a more optimized build with DIY gear. Skill focus feats seem like a waste, but there are no better feats that aren’t provided by items. There’s even allowance for item skill bonuses, even if item level restrictions are enforced.

In a setting where everyone has similar gear, the skills discipline, concentration and heal can still be very slightly useful in very rare instances. One still has to worry about disarm and taunt. The build obviously can fight unarmed, but prefers wielding dual kamas. Curse song + taunt may not reduce its 124 AC significantly, but in an unlikely moment that it is caught flat-footed in an asymmetrical battle with a horde of enemies, the AC penalty can make a difference.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
As for SCV, monk has the Empty body feat, giving 50% concealment twice per rest cycle. It lasts 1 round per monk level. So unless you do a lot of fighting between rests, the self concealment feats are not necessary.

In high magic settings, weapon enhancements can become so massive that you don't need much extra from the build itself. If divine damage is available on weapons, DM may end up being less attractive.

What is a good build in a high magic setting depends completely on what items are available and if there are custom rules and changes to the classes, feats and skills. It is also important if the build is made for PVM or PVP.

Here at the ECB most builds are made for more or less mid magic settings and PVM. We are supposed to tell what setting the build is intended for when we post a build.

The way I understand the build above, it is an attempt to explore what can be achieved by a build given a free choice of item properties up to a given total gp value. Am I right?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The "uber" 2das were a "collection" of 3 2das (afaik, correct me if I am wrong here - it's actually 1, but one can change a certain property to two other settings, making it basically "3") that basically made one into a God - they were used mostly at first by Hackers to grief Servers (and one could kill a DM with them, and since one had a "null" body, it was all but impossible to target said toon...not to mention damage ;)  Later, if my memory serves me correctly, they were used in the end stadium of PvP play, with "über haxx0rs" basically forming the top tier (where each 2da cancelled one of the others, so rock-paper-scissors) until at some point in time someone released the things to the public - either for pay-to-play or whatever (I was never in that scene, so I do not know the exact history).

So why do I know about them?

As some of you probably know, I ran my own PW on my own Server (The Playground).  It was the very first PrC enabled Server (of which I was immensely proud of, and it was a lot of fun, though the work involved getting it to work back then was excruciating!).  My team was a great team of peeps, and I hope that the many players who played there had fun.

Anyway, what does that have to do with "uber" 2das?  Well, at around that time, that is when they showed up - and PWs everywhere were being "griefed" by these hackers (might have only been one - hard to say) - they would appear on the Server and go on griefing rampages, killing Players and DMs alike with impunity.

It got so bad that the Online Community got together and formed some plans to combat this.  Since it was entirely impossible to directly target the Griefers (due to their Null bodies), someone (I am not sure who it was, might have been The Krit) came up with the idea to ID the Player in question with a widget and then use that ID to transport and jail the perp in a looping cutscene "prison" (one isolated cell with a looping cutscene in it).

That got rid of the immediate threat, and then Admins started sharing lists of banned serials as well.

That pretty much got rid of the Griefing.

Later, because I was curious about this, I found out that they were being used on high (the highest) level PvP servers.

I think I have them, kicking around somewhere in my dustbin.

Now, I am not sure if they even work anymore with EE - there have been some changes to 2da propeties, etc with EE, so I have no idea if they still are working properly.  And I don't think whoever created them is around anymore to update the things (probably a good thing) as that sort of PvP I don't think is played anymore.

One thing to mention - these "ubers" put one on the physical limits of NWN (not the ingame ones, but the actual programming limits of the code) so it was quite easy to "wrap" your values around (and therefor "break" your invulnerability, immunites, etc).  I do know that one of the strategies was to attempt to do this to your opponent, at least I was told this.  Thus, one had to carefully balance items, spells, etc to take such into consideration.

An example of this is the Stat scores - in NWN, the hard limit is 255 (yes, that is right!  You can theoretically have a 255 Str!) - it's based on 256, binary stuff, but if one tries to set the Str score to 256, it "wraps" around back to 1!  And so on...like for example, regen (don't ask me what the hard limit is for regen, I don't know!) but if one had too much, it wrapped around again, just like the Str stat in the above example.  Same goes for HPs, AC, AB, Damage, etc.  All these things have hard code limits (I guess they are value limits of the code).

So, there you have it - uber 2das in a (rough) nutshell.  Perhaps some of our more PvP experienced members know more about these (and might have a different name for them - I only know them as "uber").

Empyre65 wrote: ↑
Jan 07, 2024
There is a potential problem here.  Both monks and paladins have to be lawful, but both bards and barbarians cannot be lawful.
That’s the best schedule I can come up with given the class spread. The priorities in order are: level 40 stats > alignment changes > multiclass penalty.

The last build is similar to the previous two in that alignment shifts from lawful to non-lawful then back to lawful. However, the Pale-Disciple also has to shift from good to non-good.

Starts as lawful good. Non-lawful at level 8. After level 20, may go towards lawful before reaching level 40. Non-good as early as after level 6 and not later than level 22. Final alignment is lawful neutral/evil.
